text: I'm Andrew Knowlton restaurant and
drinks editor at bon appetit and today
I'm going to show you how to make a
classic French 75 a drink that
originated in Paris named after a famous
artillery gun used in World War one
here's how it's done very easy cocktail
to make gonna throw in an ounce of gin
you could also make this with cognac or
brandy there's some debate about what
spirit is the true one I prefer gin
which is the one I stick to to the gin
we're just gonna add a half ounce of
freshly squeezed lemon juice 1/2 ounce
of simple syrup to that we're gonna add
a little bit ice because this is a
shaking cocktail because it has fruit
juice so we're just gonna put the top on
this give it a pat because you want to
create a good seal so you should be able
to do that you can shake any way you
want the key is to shake it hard and for
15 seconds because you want dilution and
you want the cocktail to get cold you
can kind of hear when the ice starts
breaking up you don't want to shake too
long because you don't want to drink too
diluted you can serve this in a lot of
different glasses for style and a little
bit of flair it's nice to do it in a
champagne flute Quest's strain that with
a Hawthorne strainer which is the curled
wire strainer add your favorite
champagne or sparkling wine if you can
afford the good stuff use it and it
really doesn't call for a garnish or
anything but I just like to put a little
bit of lemon twist in there also just
shine through and there's the classic
aperitif cocktail the French 75 for
these cocktail recipes and more go to
Bon Appetit com
you
